content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a simple problem that utilizes modulo operation and requires you to find the maximum element.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's a great puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It used to be overly difficult but now its at a good balance I feel.

Nice problem!

I don't think giving hints is really in the spirit of Clash of Code though.
Wonderful problem. Had a great time solving it.

I like the problem a lot it's very unique. Unfortunately it took me the full 15 minutes just to figure out what was going on. Plus its difficult. It seems too difficult for a code clash (then again Im only top 2% in code clash so maybe I'm just bad). Make the problem easier to understand and also make it less difficult is my advice.

At first glance, I was questioning whether you should have specified "exclude leap years"... then I realised that only days matter; the date is irrelevant.
(I'd remove "365 = December 31st" from the goal, because sometimes 365 = December 30th - but this doesn't affect the answer)
I enjoyed this; it's not difficult (my solution is very similar to yours), but needs a little bit of thought before coding.
Oh, hmm, I thought at first that this challenge was really simple, but it's really good, great job.

Hey there!

That's my first contribution, so if there's anything I can do to make it better please tell me :)

Also, I'm not a native speaker, so I'm not sure if the statement is totally clear. If you have any suggestions to make it more easy to understand please comment here!
Thanks!

I was also wondering about the leap year situation while writing the statement and I came to the same conclusion as you.
I'm going to remove the "365 = December 31st" example, nice observation.
Thanks for the feedback!

Thanks for the feedback!

I agree that this problem is a bit harder than usual, but in my opinion it still fits CoC. Despite that, I think that it's fair to make it as easy as possible, so I added an extra paragraph. Do you think it's better now?
Thanks! :D

"I don't think giving hints is really in the spirit of Clash of Code though."

If the problem was easy, I agree. But this is different. The hints (which hardly reveal anything btw) are in the spirit of clash if the problem is too hard for the AVERAGE player to finish in 5 minutes which is what  Clash of Code is really about. You're 1st place in clash so of course you wouldn't like it but the average to below average player would.

I'm in the 2,000th rank area in clash which I believe is slightly above average and the problem took me the full 15 minutes to come up with a solution. You can just say I'm bad and you would be right, but it stands that clash is primarily built for players around my skill level and not for the people posting in this thread (highly ranked clashers).

I also think that if "Possibly helpful info if you're struggling:" was instead titled "Things to consider:", you would not have said anything. Which suggests that your issue is emotional not logical. The content is not the problem, you just don't like how it makes you feel. That's why you used the word "spirit" . And I don't think emotional reasons carry weight here. In that case, I'll just reword it.
Thanks :)
Thanks :)
Thanks :)

Thanks Haskell!

I tried to balance your suggestion to remove hints and grassworm's suggestions. Do you guys think it's ok now?
Honestly, I prefer the example instead of the hint as well just like you. Just personally, I didnt see how a hint ruins the experience especially since it wasnt even that helpful of a hint.

Thanks guys :D
I'm going to change the status to "Ready".

I think it fits CoC as well, just needs to be a bit more friendly to the average Clash coder, who are not as skilled as we'd like to think they are.

I really like the addition you made!

I've adjusted your addition trying to make it even friendlier & changed the example so its more interesting, let me know what you think:

```
Taking the days 1, 4, 5, and 6 as an example:
If Jan 1st is on a Friday => days 1, 4, 5, 6 are on Fri, Mon, Teu, Wedn respectively => 4 weekdays
If Jan 1st is on a Wedn => days land on Wedn, Sat, Su, Mon => 3 weekdays
(Answer for this example is 4)

If you're struggling, note that:
- The days 1 8 15 22 29 ... 365 will always fall on the same day of the week (same goes for 2 9 16 ... and so on)
- You'll find that leap years & the days in a month are irrelevant to the nature of the problem
```

Also the example for input output should be more interesting.

You can use the same example you used in your description.

Thanks for the suggestion, but I think that the problem is already a bit over-explained :sweat_smile:

I also think that the example should be a more interesting case, but according to the guidelines the first test should be the simplest one (and that's the one displayed as the example)

Don't let the guidelines lead you astray. I know the guidelines say that but their purpose is to describe a test case to help the user.

The test case right now is literally just 7. Alot of users depend on this for help and its not helpful.

I agree & I changed my addition in response to what you said. Now its just:
Ex. days 1, 4, 5, and 6:
If Jan 1st is on a Friday => days 1, 4, 5, 6 are on Fri, Mon, Teu, Wedn respectively => 4 weekdays

I SERIOUSLY think the above inclusion should replace your entire last paragraph if you're worried about overexplaining.

While your addition is helpful, compared to my suggestion I think it just gives more tedious reading imo, but my suggestion is fast to read and helpful. Remember, you're giving a problem to people MUCH less skilled than you & the people commenting on this thread.
Just added the example, do you think it's good now?

Thanks for the addition, man. I did some tweaks to make the content more easily readable.

Also, while "Possibly helpful info if you're struggling" might seem strange to read, its (1) more honest & (2) not confusing for readers.

It basically tells really good coders who understand the problem that they can ignore the paragraph and not waste their time. Certain coders might be even MORE confused after reading the last paragraph, so the statement "possibly helpful" lets them know they can ignore the information if they want to.
Also, I still think the last bullet point should be removed but hey its not that big of a deal if you want to keep it.

I updated the statement again.

In my opinion the example with 4 days that results in a maximum of 3 simultaneous weekdays is more helpful, since it's kinda obvious that there are cases where 4 days can simultaneously fall on weekdays, but I left both there anyway.

And I think that editing the statement without asking even after I accepted almost all of your suggestions (adapting to a way that I think is more legible) wasn't very nice, even that I know that you made it with good intentions.

"And I think that editing the statement without asking even after I accepted almost all of your suggestions (adapting to a way that I think is more legible) wasn't very nice, even that I know that you made it with good intentions."

Yeah my intentions were good, no harm meant and I'm sorry there was a disconnect. I didn't want to make you feel that way.

On that topic, maybe you disagree with me here, but since all "experienced" clashers have edit privileges and any of them can edit...I assume that the way this works is like a Wikipedia article. As soon as you write up a Wiki article, you no longer own it. You forfeit all ownership to the community. So therefore, I should be allowed to edit the problem description (only making responsible changes that I strongly consider direct improvements). Of course, in the worst case scenario that I'm being stupid, anyone can just fix it. So it works out. If I need your permission first, its actually a dictatorship right? Does that make sense?

"In my opinion the example with 4 days that results in a maximum of 3 simultaneous weekdays is more helpful, since it's kinda obvious that there are cases where 4 days can simultaneously fall on weekdays, but I left both there anyway."

I like your change. I understand you'd like to remove my example, but I propose a compromise that I think you'll like. We remove my example completely, but we add one more sentence to your example like so:

```
Taking the days  {{1}}, {{3}}, {{5}}, {{6}} as an example, at least one day will always fall on a weekend, regardless of which day of the week Jan 1st falls on (so expected answer would be 3). E.g. One possibility is Jan 1st falling on a Friday, making days  {{1}}, {{3}}, {{5}}, {{6}} fall on Friday, Sunday, Tuesday, Wednesday respectively.
```

Oh, I think that calling this a dictatorship is a bit too strong, I think that it's something more like opening a PR to an open source project :sweat_smile:

Thanks for the suggestion, but I liked the comparison of the two examples containing four days. Can we keep it?
Yeah thats fine, great job. Only reason I complained for this problem is cause its a fun problem to do.  High quality.

Thanks!
And I thinks it's better now with the extra paragraph and the more helpful test case as the example :)
